sciknow-25x1-scientific-papers.abstract: This research aims to compare the performance and security between Json Web Token (JWT) and Platform Agnostic Security Tokens (PASETO) on RESTful API. Performance is measured through the parameters of token generation time, token size, and token transfer time, while security is measured through the top three API OWASP 2019 vulnerabilities and testing CSRF attacks on tokens. The results from 50 samples show that the average token generation time of JWT is 0.5068 ms and PASETO is 2.4044 ms. The average transfer time of JWT tokens is 95.4604 ms and PASETO 190.4344 ms. The T-test results confirm the significant difference between token generation time and token transfer time in JWT and PASETO. In addition, the number of PASETO tokens generated is also greater at 320 tokens compared to JWT at 186 tokens. In security testing, JWT tokens are proven safe from OWASP 2019 API attacks, such as Broken Object Level Authorization and Excessive Data Exposure, but are not safe from Broken User Authentication attacks. PASETO tokens were shown to be safe from all three attacks. However, neither JWT nor PASETO tokens are safe from CSRF Cookie attacks. The result can be concluded that PASETO has a longer token generation time and transfer time compared to JWT. However, PASETO shows a higher level of security compared to JWT, as it can protect against the top three attacks of the OWASP 2019 API.
sciknow-25x1-scientific-papers.journal: while security is measured through the top three API OWASP

sciknow-25x1-research-problems.problemStatement: The research addresses the need to compare the performance and security of Json Web Token (JWT) and Platform Agnostic Security Tokens (PASETO) in RESTful API services, focusing on token generation time, token size, token transfer time, and resilience to common API vulnerabilities and CSRF attacks.
sciknow-25x1-research-problems.problemScope: The scope includes measuring performance parameters (token generation time, token size, token transfer time) and security against OWASP 2019 API vulnerabilities and CSRF attacks for JWT and PASETO tokens.
sciknow-25x1-research-problems.problemImportance: Understanding the performance and security differences between JWT and PASETO is crucial for developers and researchers to implement more efficient and secure RESTful API authentication tokens.
sciknow-25x1-research-problems.businessRelevance: Improving the security and efficiency of API authentication tokens is vital for protecting against data breaches, accidental data exposure, and other security vulnerabilities, which have significant implications for business operations and customer trust.

sciknow-25x1-knowledge-gaps.gapDescription: JWT and PASETO tokens have not been tested for security which includes the none algorithm exploitation test, and the OWASP API Security Top 10 test and there is no performance testing and security testing in the form of CSRF penetration tests on JWT and PASETO in versions and algorithms that have the same characteristics.
sciknow-25x1-knowledge-gaps.gapSignificance: Understanding the security and performance of JWT and PASETO tokens is crucial for developers and researchers to implement more efficient and secure RESTful API authentication tokens.

sciknow-25x1-research-questions.questionText: How do the performance metrics of token generation time, token size, and token transfer time compare between Json Web Token (JWT) and Platform Agnostic Security Tokens (PASETO) on RESTful API?
What is the level of security provided by JWT and PASETO tokens against the top three API OWASP 2019 vulnerabilities and CSRF attacks?

sciknow-25x1-methodological-frameworks.name: Comparative Testing of JWT and PASETO Authentication Tokens
sciknow-25x1-methodological-frameworks.description: The study aims to compare the performance and security of JWT and PASETO authentication tokens in RESTful API environments. The performance is evaluated based on token generation time, token size, and token transfer time. Security is assessed through the top three API vulnerabilities listed in OWASP 2019 and CSRF attack testing. The methodological framework includes the Design Research Methodology (DRM) with the Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC) Waterfall model, consisting of Research Clarification, Descriptive Study I, Perspective Study, and Descriptive Study II.

studyDesign.designDetails: The study uses an experimental design to compare JWT and PASETO tokens' performance and security. The DRM and SDLC Waterfall model guide the research process through structured stages.

variables.conceptualDefinition: The time taken to generate authentication tokens.
variables.operationalization: Measured in milliseconds using the performance.now() function during token generation.

variables.conceptualDefinition: The size of the authentication token.
variables.operationalization: Measured by the number of tokens generated within a given time frame.

variables.conceptualDefinition: The time taken to transfer the authentication token from the server to the client.
variables.operationalization: Measured in milliseconds using the Postman application during API login.

variables.conceptualDefinition: The susceptibility of the authentication token to security threats.
variables.operationalization: Assessed through testing against the top three OWASP 2019 API vulnerabilities and CSRF attacks.

steps.description: Build RESTful API with JWT and PASETO token authentication.
steps.inputs: JWT and PASETO token authentication mechanisms
steps.outputs: RESTful API environment ready for testing

steps.description: Measure token generation time using performance.now() function.
Count the number of tokens generated within a given time frame.
Measure token transfer time using Postman application during API login.
Conduct security testing against OWASP API Security Top Ten 2019 vulnerabilities.
Perform CSRF penetration testing on cookie storage.

procedures.procedureDescription: The procedure involves testing the performance of JWT and PASETO tokens by measuring token generation time, token size, and token transfer time. Security testing includes evaluating the tokens against the top three OWASP API Security Top Ten 2019 vulnerabilities and CSRF penetration testing.

dataAnalysis.summary: Data analysis includes the use of an independent sample t-test to compare the token generation and transfer times between JWT and PASETO. The security of the tokens is evaluated through black box testing methods against predefined test cases based on OWASP API Security Top Ten 2019 and CSRF attacks.

resultsRepresentation.summary: The results indicate that PASETO tokens have a longer generation and transfer time compared to JWT. However, PASETO tokens demonstrate a higher level of security by protecting against all three of the top OWASP 2019 API attacks, whereas JWT tokens are vulnerable to Broken User Authentication attacks. Neither token type is safe from CSRF Cookie attacks.

sciknow-25x1-material-tools.roleInProcedure: Used for driving nails into wood
